title: 111_hr1472
content: The Act may be cited as the "TARP and ARRA Reporting and Waste Prevention Act" and includes a reporting requirement. Every entity must report to the Treasury Secretary within 30 days of receiving or redistributing funds from the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 or the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. The report should include the amount of funds, recipient entity, specific authorization provisions, and the purpose of the funds. Entities receiving funds must provide detailed information on the purpose, geographic area, and use of the funds, along with copies of any related contracts. Additionally, entities entering into contracts must submit reports to the Treasury Secretary every 30 days detailing the contract's performance until completion. Entities receiving funds must provide detailed information on the purpose, geographic area, and use of the funds, along with copies of any related contracts. Additionally, they must submit reports to the Treasury Secretary detailing the amount of funds expended, specific details of expenditures, job creation, and geographic areas where funds were spent. Commingled funds with funds distributed under certain acts are also subject to reporting requirements. Entities receiving funds must provide detailed information on the purpose, geographic area, and use of the funds, along with copies of any related contracts. They must submit reports to the Treasury Secretary detailing the amount of funds expended, specific details of expenditures, job creation, and geographic areas where funds were spent. Commingled funds from specific acts are subject to reporting requirements, with regulations to be issued within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. No reporting is needed for funds received under certain tax benefits. Entities redistributing funds must notify recipients that the funds are from the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 or the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. Recipients may need to report on the use of these funds under the TARP and ARRA Reporting and Waste Prevention Act. Non-compliance by private entities may result in penalties. Private entities failing to submit required reports may be barred from federal contracts, grants, loans, or funds if the failure was intentional and the entity's leadership was aware of the reporting requirement. The term "heads of the private entity" includes the board of directors and officers. The term "public or private entity" includes Federal agencies, State government departments, political subdivisions, and private entities. Funds distributed under certain acts are considered "redistributed" when passed from one entity to another. The term "redistribution" excludes distributions for purchasing equipment or supplies and services incidental to such purchases. This section becomes effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish a federal database to hold information reported under section 2, which will be made available to the public on recovery.gov. Additionally, a waste, fraud, and abuse hotline will be implemented. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish a national toll-free hotline for reporting waste, fraud, or abuse related to funds distributed under specific acts. Quarterly reports to Congress will detail compliance and actions taken. Whistleblower protection is provided for individuals reporting such instances. Employees are protected from retaliation for reporting waste, fraud, or abuse related to funds distributed under specific acts. This includes providing information, assisting in investigations, or filing complaints. Employees are protected from retaliation for reporting waste, fraud, or abuse related to funds distributed under specific acts by filing complaints with the Secretary of Labor. Employees protected from retaliation for reporting issues related to funds can bring a legal action if the Secretary of Labor does not issue a final decision within 180 days. The action will be governed by specific rules and procedures. Employees protected from retaliation for reporting issues related to funds can bring a legal action within 90 days of the violation occurring. The action will be governed by the legal burdens of proof set forth in section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code. An employee prevailing in an action for discrimination is entitled to reinstatement, back pay with interest, and compensation for special damages. Nothing in this section affects the rights retained by the employee. (4) Rights retained by employee.--This subsection does not diminish the rights of any employee under Federal or State law, or under any collective bargaining agreement. The Recovery Accountability and Transparency Board can request audits or inspections from Inspector Generals, with the results being made public on recovery.gov.
